title: Ministers 'consider sending migrants to UK overseas territories' if Rwanda plan fails
body:
Get the free Morning Headlines email for news from our reporters across the world Sign up to our free Morning Headlines email Please enter a valid email address Please enter a valid email address SIGN UP I would like to be emailed about offers, events and updates from The Independent. Read our privacy notice Thanks for signing up to the

Morning Headlines email {{ #verifyErrors }} {{ message }} {{ /verifyErrors }} {{ ^verifyErrors }} Something went wrong. Please try again later {{ /verifyErrors }}

Ministers are reportedly reconsidering proposals to send migrants to British overseas territories if their Rwanda plan fails.

Ascension Island is among the territories being re-evaluated as a place to process asylum seekers – in case the government's Rwanda policy is ruled unlawful by the Supreme Court, The Times has reported.

The government is also reportedly in negotiations with at least five other countries over a similar deportation agreement to the one agreed with Rwanda.

Labour's shadow home secretary, Yvette Cooper, condemned the plans as "headline chasing announcements that are never delivered".

Asylum seekers sent to these territories would not be able to remain there permanently. The success of the proposal would rely on the government being able to relocate migrants to another destination – such as their home country or a third party country – after their claims are processed.

Previous plans to send illegal migrants to Ascension Island, revealed in 2020 under Boris Johnson and Priti Patel's tenure, were branded a "logistical nightmare" by a member of the island's council, Alan Nicholls.

A feasibility study carried out by the Foreign Office found the volcanic island, with a population of 900, was "unlivable" for reasons such as inadequate water supplies, and a lack of medical infrastructure.

The government's Rwanda plan ran into legal roadblocks after the Court of Appeal found it was "unlawful", citing deficiencies in the East African country's asylum system.

A senior government source told The Times that it was "pragmatic to consider all options" including sending illegal migrants to overseas territories such as Ascension Island.

The chief executive of the Refugee Council, Enver Solomon, condemned these proposals as "more shameful demonisation of men, women and children" escaping countries such as Afghanistan, Sudan, and Iran.

Labour's Yvette Cooper told the paper: "They claimed they were going to do this years ago but it never got off the ground. This joins a long list of headline chasing announcements that are never delivered."

Campaigners have raised concerns about the safety of people deported to Rwanda (PA) (PA Wire)

The government is also considering significantly increasing fines for employers and landlords who allow unauthorised migrants to work for them or live in their properties, under their plans to deter Channel crossings.

The Home Office argued that "illegal working and renting are significant pull factors for migrants crossing the Channel" and that increasing fines will serve as a deterrent.

Civil penalties for employers will be increased up to a maximum of £45,000 per worker for a first breach and £60,000 for repeat offenders, tripling both from the last increase in 2014.

These hikes are expected to be enforced from the beginning of next year, after the laws are altered this autumn.

Immigration minister Robert Jenrick said: "Unscrupulous landlords and employers who allow illegal working and renting enable the business model of the evil people smugglers to continue."

"There is no excuse for not conducting the appropriate checks and those in breach will now face significantly tougher penalties," he added.

taxonomy_info.explanation: The article explicitly names Yvette Cooper and identifies her as Labour's shadow home secretary, matching both the name and the description.

reasoning.identity_verification_and_presence: The article explicitly names "Labour's shadow home secretary, Yvette Cooper" and later quotes her directly. This matches the Wikidata entity’s name, party affiliation (Labour Party), and current role (Shadow Home Secretary, as of the article’s timeframe). No other person named Yvette Cooper is mentioned, and the context (Labour, shadow home secretary) aligns perfectly with the Wikidata description.
reasoning.statement_assessment: Yvette Cooper is quoted twice in the article: once condemning the plans and once elaborating on the issue. The attribution is clear and direct, indicating she is making statements.
reasoning.plausibility_assessment: It is entirely plausible for the Labour shadow home secretary to comment on government migration proposals, especially given her role in opposition to the policy. The statements are consistent with her position.
reasoning.contradiction_analysis: No contradictions are found between the article’s depiction of Yvette Cooper and the Wikidata profile.

reasoning.identity_verification_and_presence: The article mentions a person named Alan Nicholls who is described as a member of Ascension Island's council. The Wikidata entity with the same name is an English footballer (born 1973, died 1995) with no connection to Ascension Island or any council role. The name alone is insufficient for a match; the contextual details (occupation, role, location) differ fundamentally. Therefore the Wikidata entity is not the same real‑world person referenced in the article.

reasoning.presence_detection: The article explicitly mentions "A feasibility study carried out by the Foreign Office". This matches the target entity name "Foreign Office" and the description that the study was conducted by it. Therefore the target organization is present in the text.
reasoning.statement_detection: No direct quotes, reported speech, or explicit statements attributed to the Foreign Office are present. The article reports the findings of a study produced by the Foreign Office, but it does not attribute a statement or declaration to the organization itself. Hence, statement attribution is not applicable.
reasoning.candidate_evaluation: Candidate Q358834 (Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office) is a UK government department that matches the name "Foreign Office" and the context of conducting a feasibility study. Candidate Q600040 (Foreign Office Architects) is an architectural firm unrelated to the described activity. Thus Q358834 is the best match.
reasoning.authority_verification: N/A – no statements were attributed to the organization in the article, so authority verification is not required.
reasoning.plausibility_assessment: N/A – there are no statements to assess for plausibility.
reasoning.final_justification: The target organization is clearly present in the article as the producer of the feasibility study. The only suitable candidate from the list that aligns with the name, type, and described activity is Q358834. No direct statements are made by the organization, so attribution is not needed. The answer is the Wikidata ID of the matching candidate.

The name alone is insufficient for a match, and the contextual details (country, legal context) contradict the Wikidata description.

reasoning.identity_verification_and_presence: The article explicitly names "Immigration minister Robert Jenrick" and quotes him. This matches the Wikidata entity name and the description "Immigration minister". The context (UK government policy on migrants) aligns with his known role as Minister of State for Immigration (though his term ended in December 2023, the article refers to him in that capacity, which is consistent with the time of the article). No other individual named Robert Jenrick is mentioned, and the role and title match the Wikidata profile, so the entity is present and identifiable.
reasoning.statement_assessment: Robert Jenrick is directly quoted: "Unscrupulous landlords and employers who allow illegal working and renting enable the business model of the evil people smugglers to continue." and "There is no excuse for not conducting the appropriate checks and those in breach will now face significantly tougher penalties." These are clear statements attributed to him.
reasoning.plausibility_assessment: It is highly plausible for the former Minister of State for Immigration to make such statements about immigration enforcement and penalties, as it falls squarely within his ministerial remit.
reasoning.contradiction_analysis: No contradictions are found between the article content and the Wikidata profile. The only minor discrepancy is the end date of his ministerial role (2023‑12‑06) versus the article’s present‑tense reference; however, the article’s context (policy discussion) still fits his former position.
